com.hunterjdev.mockjdbc

Class MockDriver

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.hunterjdev.mockjdbc.MockDriver

  • public class MockDriver
extends java.lang.Object
    MockDriver provides a container to run and test JDBC code with mock objects. Proxy objects are substituted for the typically used objects within the java.sql package, namely Driver, Connection, Statement, and ResultSet.

    The primary design consideration for MockDriver is to give test classes a mechanism for feeding data, from mock ResultSet objects, to the application code under test. The mock ResultSet objects provide the input that would normally be provided by the database, thus decoupling the test code from dependency on the database. The testing code then tests the application only. This approach is not intended to replace end-to-end testing or functional testing with an actual RDBMS.

    Mock ResultSet objects are simple Java Objects, which do not need to implement a specific interface. The only requirement for mock ResultSet objects is that they define methods which are identical to methods which are expected to be called on actual java.sql.ResultSet objects by the application code under test. These "mock methods" provide meaningful data which would, otherwise come from the database.

    TestAction instances are used to encapsulate the testing code which needs to be run within the MockDriver context. TestAction instances are specified as arguments to the execute(TestAction) methods. For example (here, using an anonymous TestAction type): 

         TestAction testAction = new TestAction("Some Awesome Test") {
         @Override
         public void runTest() {
             testSomething();
             ...
         }
     });
     MockDriver driver = new MockDriver(mockResultSet);
     driver.setupConnectionSource();
     driver.execute(testAction);
     driver.restoreConnectionSource();

    Since most of the typical database access code relies on a ResultSet object for data, there was very little consideration for supporting methods in Statement, and its sub-classes, which return anything but a ResultSet - such as, the various Statement.executeXXX methods. These methods usually execute some update to the database, rather than data retrieval, and sometimes return a boolean or int value indicating some result. But the return values for these methods are rarely used. If a test writer needs to supply a mock method for one of these methods, this can be accomplished by extending MockDriver and overriding the newProxyStatement(Class) method, to provide a custom java.lang.reflect InvocationHandler. In fact, all of the newProxyXXX methods can be considered as extension points to handle special cases.

    The one known limitation is the inability to create a proxy object which needs to be cast to a concrete type. The Java proxy mechanism can only create a proxy object from interfaces.

    Version:
    1.0
    Author:
    James Hunter

      • getClassBindings

        public java.util.Map<java.lang.Class<?>,java.lang.Class<?>> getClassBindings()
        Class bindings are stored in a Map. Class bindings are used to bind a sub-type interface to its parent interface in order to provide the correct interface type to the calling code, For example: 
         com.mysql.jdbc.Statement stmt = (com.mysql.jdbc.Statement) connection.createStatement();
        The Java proxy mechanism will detect the return type above as a java.sql.Statement. But the caller casts it to a sub-type. If the proxy object is not built with the correct return type, a ClassCastException is likely to occur. So, the class bindings, then, supply the correct return type.
        Returns:
        the class bindings Map.

      • setupConnectionSource

        public void setupConnectionSource()
                           throws java.lang.Exception
        This method must be called prior to execute(TestAction), so that the proxy JDBC driver will be invoked, instead of any other drivers registered with the DriverManager.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • restoreConnectionSource

        public void restoreConnectionSource()
                             throws java.lang.Exception
        This method must be invoked after the test action, in order to re-register the original JDBC drivers with the DriverManager. It's up to the test writer to know when the original drivers need to be restored.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

        Returns:

      • newProxyConnection

        public java.lang.Object newProxyConnection(java.lang.Class<?> type)
        This proxy type represents a java.sql.Connection. It is made public for cases where a Connection object can be injected into the code under test. Derived classes can override this method to supply a custom InvocationHandler.
        Parameters:
        type -
        Returns:
        a proxy object which can be caste to the class type which is bound to the specified type.

      • newProxyDriver

        protected java.sql.Driver newProxyDriver()
        Derived classes can override this method to supply a custom InvocationHandler.
        Returns:
        a proxy object as a java.sql.Driver.

      • execute

        public void execute(TestAction testAction)
             throws java.lang.Exception
        Called to execute a particular test action within the mock driver container. setupConnectionSource() must be called prior to this method. restoreConnectionSource() must be called before exiting the test case, or before executing another test which depends on the actual system JDBC drivers.
        Parameters:
        testAction -
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception
